H0.text: Chickens that naturally make the antibiotics are the organisms whose natural selection will most likely be influenced by the overuse of antibiotics used to treat infections in humans and chickens, a practice that some groups oppose.

H1.text: Microbes that are resistant to the antibiotics are the organisms most likely to be influenced by natural selection when antibiotics used to treat infections in humans are also used in chickens, a practice that some groups oppose.

H2.text: Microbes that are susceptible to the antibiotics are most likely to undergo natural selection due to the overuse of antibiotics used to treat infections in humans and chickens, a practice opposed by some groups.

H3.text: Chickens that are resistant to infection are the organisms whose natural selection is most likely influenced by the overuse of antibiotics used to treat infections in both humans and chickens.

A4.text: The prophylactic use of 'non-priority' or 'non-clinically relevant' antimicrobials in feeds can potentially, under certain conditions, lead to co-selection of environmental AMR bacteria with resistance to medically important antibiotics.

A5.text: Some contemporary antimicrobial resistances have also evolved naturally before the use of antimicrobials of human clinical uses.

A6.text: Hence the practice of using antibiotics for growth stimulation could result in selection for resistance.

A7.text: used irresponsibly, this may lead to antibiotic resistance which may impact human, animal and environmental health.
